Award.AwardTitle: Emerging Research-Empirical: Development and Application of a Multilevel Multiple-Group CDM to Compare Cognitive Attribute Distributions based on Eighth Grade TIMSS Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research project will develop new extensions of cognitive diagnostic models (CDM) to understand what math skills U.S. students possess or lack, and compare the distributions of skills across countries and within countries across years. The research team will examine the relationship between these skills and core background variables (e.g., gender). The research focuses on the TIMSS eighth grade mathematics assessments from 1999, 2003, and 2007. To handle the complex sampling design used in TIMSS, the PIs will develop the multi-group CDM to account for the clustering of students within schools. Whereas the TIMSS framework identifies only a single skill for each item (e.g., ability to calculate area) the proposed research will identify multiple skills for each item. This qualitative analysis is required as part of the CDM, but is also important to better understand the TIMSS assessments.

The statistical methods developed as part of this research will allow a thorough analysis of the TIMSS assessment data. As part of the proposed research, the principal investigators will work with math education researchers and measurement experts to develop statistical models and codes to analyze assessment data. Although the proposed research focuses on eighth grade TIMSS mathematics data, the statitical methods will have implications for use with other national and international data and assessments (e.g., NAEP and PISA). Policy makers will be able to use this information to make well-informed decisions about curriculum changes. Future studies will be able to use the methods to examine different age groups (e.g., 4th grade), different subject areas (e.g., science), and different assessments (e.g., NAEP and PISA).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Students in the United States have consistently performed below many of their international peers on mathematics assessments like TIMSS and PISA. This gap in performance is usually described in terms of a few very broad content domains (e.g., Algebra, Geometry), but it remains unclear exactly what math skills U.S. students are missing. This research developed and applied methods based on a class of psychometric models called cognitive diagnostic models to understand exactly what math skills U.S. students lack, and compared the distributions of skills across countries and within country across years. The research examined TIMSS eighth grade mathematics assessments from 1999, 2003, 2007, and 2011.

The initial stages of the research were devoted to developing the statistical methods for performing a cognitive diagnostic analysis of large-scale assessment data that was sampled from a complex clustered design. Adapting methods similar to those utilized for the analysis of National Assessment of Educational Progress data, we were able to develop methods for comparing different groups of students in terms of their academic skill profiles. Through well-designed simulation studies, we were able to verify that our methods produced valid statistical results. 

Our investigation of historical TIMSS data identified nine assessed skills or attributes: Whole Numbers & Integers; Fractions, Decimals & Percentages; Ratios & Proportions; Patterns; Expression, Equations & Functions; Lines, Angles & Shapes; Measurement; Location & Movement; and Data Analysis & Probability. Our analyses focused on American students (both from a national sample and benchmark state samples from Massachusetts and Minnesota) and students from countries that outperformed the US students according to the overall TIMSS scaled scores. These countries were Chinese Taipei, Republic of Korea, Singapore, Hong Kong, Japan, Hungary, England, and Russia.

The included figure illustrates the attribute prevalence by country. To aid in analysis, the nine attributes identified in the TIMSS assessment were organized by their respective content areas: Number & Operation, Algebra, Geometry, and Data & Probability. The countries and states were ordered based on the reported 2007 TIMSS 2007 score rankings. Results show that while attribute prevalence roughly decreased in step with a decrease in overall performance, there were some exceptions. We found that a relatively low proportion of students from the United States have mastered the Patterns, Lines, Angles, & Shapes attribute in the Geometry domain and the Ratios & Proportions in the Number & Operation domain. In contrast, a relatively high proportion of students in the United States have mastered the Data & Probability attribute. This is especially true in Minnesota and Massachusetts, where the prevalence of this attribute nearly matched or exceeded those found in the high-performing countries such as Taiwan, Singapore, and Hong Kong.

Our analysis comparing male and female students within the United States suggests that a simple mean shift model in performance does not adequately describe the differences in performance between male and female students. Specifically we found that while there were differences on all nine of the attributes measured by the TIMSS assessment, the differences were not uniform. In fact, a higher proportion of male students demonstrated expertise on only 7 of the 9 skills, whereas a statistically significant (p-val <.01) higher proportion of female students mastered the Patterns and Expression, Equations & Functions  skills measured by the TIMSS assessment. While male students have mastered the skills at a higher rate than female students, it appeared that the gaps in mastery have been shrinking over the time.
